audio_caption: The audio starts with a friendly greeting, leading into an instructional tone as a female speaker introduces a tutorial on bond formation in JChemPaint. The speaker outlines the tutorial's learning objectives, which include adding and orienting bonds, adding stereochemical bonds, and inverting wedge hashes. Technical details about the software version and the Ubuntu Linux OS are provided, alongside a note about the prerequisite knowledge of JChemPaint. The speaker suggests visiting a website for relevant tutorials if needed.

The clip begins with a female speaker announcing the opening of a new ChemPaint application and its focus on ethane structure. She proposes to explore the conversion of saturated hydrocarbons to unsaturated ones in an instructional tone.

The clip starts with a female speaker instructing to copy and paste an ethane structure twice on the display area. She maintains a clear and informative tone throughout. She goes on to explain how to use selection tools, copy and paste functions, and move overlapping structures. She then shifts to describing the visible single bond between carbon atoms in the structures.

The audio clip features a single, calm, and steady female speaker describing the process of converting a single bond to a double bond, mentioning phrases like "add a bond" and "double bond". She explains the reduction of hydrogen atoms and identifies the resulting structure as ethene. There are no other sounds in the background.

The audio features a single, female speaker who narrates instructions on a scientific topic, likely related to chemistry, with a calm and informative tone. She describes converting "the single bond to a triple bond," detailing actions like clicking on an existing bond and observing the conversion and the reduction of hydrogen atoms. The narrator then introduces "ethyne" as the new structure.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker instructing someone to "write the names of the structures". She then guides the listener to "click on add or modify a text tool" and "click below the structures". The speaker follows up by instructing to "enter the names of the structures" listing "ethane", "ethene", and "ethyne".

The audio clip starts with a female speaker introducing "tetrahedral geometry" and suggesting to move the structures to the side. She then instructs to "press control A to select all objects" and click on the "select one or more objects tool" and drag the structures. The speaker speaks in an instructional tone.

The audio clip begins with a female voice describing the tetrahedral methane structure, mentioning bond lengths and angles in a clear and informative tone. Following this explanation, a sound is perceived, but its nature is uncertain.

A female speaker starts by initiating the process of drawing a tetrahedral ethane structure. She instructs the listener to "click on add a bond", "orient the bond", and create three bonds, emphasizing a "tetrahedral geometry." The speaker guides the listener on how to attach hydrogen atoms by pressing "capital H", and selecting "H", clarifying that the hydrogen atom should appear in the toolbox. Finally, she prompts the listener to "click on all the positions to add hydrogen atoms."

A female speaker begins by introducing the addition of stereochemical bonds to an ethane structure. She proceeds to describe the stereochemical bonds available in the toolbox, including the wedge bond, hash bond, swiggle bond, and four bond. The speaker suggests using the wedge bond to convert ethane to a stereochemical structure. The speaker then provides further instructions to click on the wedge bond tool and click on all the bonds. Finally, the speaker instructs to observe the changes and click on the hash bond tool before clicking on the display area.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker introducing and explaining "invert wedge hashes" using a clear and instructional tone. She describes how to access the relevant settings within a program's menu, specifically mentioning the "edit menu" and "preferences" window. She explains that the "invert wedge hashes" checkbox, when checked, will cause "wedge hashes bond will follow the usual convention" with "narrow end is at the start" and "broad end is at the other end". The speaker details how this setting impacts visualization of the bond and that the default in "G Kemp Paint is inverse". She mentions it "is more consistent with the perspective rules". She describes to "observe the changes in the hash bond". She instructs the listener to click on "close button to close the window".

The clip starts with a female speaker instructing someone to "change the bonds to add a hash bond in the ethane structure", her tone is instructional. She then commands to "click on add a hash bond" and then to "click on all the bonds". After this she asks to "save the file".

A female speaker with an instructional tone begins by saying "click on save the current file icon." She continues to provide further directions, mentioning "save as dialog box opens" and "enter the file name as formation of bonds." The speaker concludes with "click on save button" and "let us summarize."

The audio clip begins with a single female speaker summarizing a tutorial, mentioning adding and orienting bonds, including stereochemical ones, and inverse wedges. She then introduces an assignment to convert propane to propine, draw propane and butane structures, and show stereochemical bonds, stating that the completed assignment should look a certain way. The speaker has a clear and informative tone.

The clip starts with a female voice introducing the Spoken Tutorial project, summarizing its activities and providing contact information, spoken in an informative tone. A single male voice then concludes the clip by saying "So."

The clip starts with a female speaker informing us that the spoken tutorial project is a part of the talk-to-a-teacher project. She continues by explaining that this project is supported by the National Mission on Education, adding that more information is available via a provided link. She then credits Udaya Chandrika with the animation. After this, a different female speaker identifies herself as Madhuri Ganapathi from IIT Bombay and says "signing off", followed by "Thank you for joining."
